I don't recommend this game for only one reason - Anno 1404, its predacessor, is SO much better.  This entry in the series is a technical advance, but it has taken the organic feel of 1404 and sterilised it, losing a lot in the process. Much of the appeal of the original was finding your own solution to a very broad set of objectives, but 2070 adds a campaign that provides a rigid structure to the missions that feels far too constrained, and it has thrown in additional mechanics that serve only to restrict how you can build and interact with the world.  If you enjoy these kinds of management games, I'd recommend picking up 1404 plus its expansion, Venice, before even considering Anno 2070.

It's easy to sink hours into a game and not reach the endgame, or even the midgame. If you are a fan of real time strategy games like Age of Empires, then this game is a perfect purchase for you. This award winning mixture of diplomacy, war and construction is sure to win you over to it.

**Pro's** Tons of replay and achevements Nice graphics Low system requirements Challanging to play with tons of micromagament 2 and a half playable factions **Con's** Tons of micromanagement, if you dont like that. Uplay & DRM  **Detailed walkthrough of experience** The game is beautiful and runs very well on my 9 year old PC with max graphics. Causes a little system lag with other programs but minimizing the game fixes this problem in my experience. Outside of small bugs here and there you will encounter in any game this game runs flawlessly with some of the best pathing AI I have seen. Alot of stuff has to be unlocked though gameplay such as player colors, you start out with 4 or 5 colors and unlock more by playing for specific factions durring missions or free play when you complete achevements or special missions in the name of those factions.  Graphically the world is very alive.... you can see towns foke walking around the streets, cars zipping around, police/fire/ambulances running from their buildings to emergency sites including things like hazmat teams quarenteening a house if an epidemic breaks out or fire coming out of a buildings windows if theirs a fire. The world changes based upon its Eco balance, the higher you get the greener and brighter everything seems, the lower you get the darker and gloomier everything looks. BAsed on gameplay settings the eco balance even has effects on your island, causing things like tornados (negative) or tropical thunder storms (positive).  DLC is so well integrated into the game that you can bairly tell it wasnt a basic function, Im still lost on what some of the DLC is or does cause I bought the game and DLC all at once durring the summer sale. Most of the DLC is cosmetic items, such as fountains and parks that can add varity to how your cities look but is completely optional. Other DLC include technologys you cannot get though base game play such as the Eco Balance building Keeper 1.0, New player/account protrates/colors, a few new units, new missions. The only actual expansion to the game itself how ever is Deep Ocean, It adds a new civilization level to the technology faction, S.A.A.T, as well as new missions, buildings, achevements, technologies, disasters and more. If you buy any DLC Deep ocean is a must.  Modules and technology allow for nearly limitless customization, and micromagament can either be a fun or hair pulling experence. Missions are well made and challange you. Even with 100 hours into the game some missions are even still to hard for me to complete.  All maps are randomly generated based on values you can set in before generating the world. There is even artifacts that can be abled from past civilizations that effect the eco balance positively or negatively to even further add varity and challange to gameplay.  2 and a half factions make this game very replayable, and due to the randomization of every map only more so. Why I say 2 and a half factions is because the 3rd research faction, S.A.A.T, does not have basic construction buildings for things like construction blocks or tools, making it impossible to play on its own. It is a supliment to the other two. Even mixing the basic two factions, Tycoons and Eco Warriors, can have benifits. Spit islands and use mining points for iron and copper and use the Tycoons coal diggers to fuel the smelters to provide Eco Warriors with tools to construct Eco Balance buildings. Thats just a simple example of how using both can come to an advantage.  Continus gameplay is astonishing in this game, unlike most I have seen. You can build a civilization, get some base work done, stock up on some materials, load it all into your arc and leave. Start a new map and use all of that stockpile to quickly build a new civilization and keep going. Technology unlocks from research are account unlocks, meaning if you unlock it its unlocked forever. This does add a bit of a 'level cap' of sorts to the game but you can always choose to restart by emptying everything, including technology upgrades from your arc and starting fresh with no help from previous games if you wish to keep playing continus mode. You can disable continus play all togeather in the game options when you make a map. Research how ever unless you disable it in the game options, is perminant, I havent figured out how to reset that other then to make a new account and buy the game again.  I only have 1 comment to make on Uplay. Its useless. I dont mean Uplay itself is usesless, or poorly made, its just not needed, not required. You have to install the game though steam, download Uplay (automatic if you install with steam), make a Uplay account, Update the game. When you launch it from steam, steam launches Uplay then Uplay launches Anno 2070. Its annoying but has never gotten in the way. Steam Ingame overlay works, but you need to readd your friends to Uplays friends list to play online with them less I missed something  Online play is smooth and challanging in its own right though buyer be ware, DRM on this game is 24/7. BEFORE you panic, the game WILL run if you have launched it once with steam running, but all achements and online play will be disabled if you are playing in offline mode. Because certain things like research unlocks, Ark Storage and the like are bound to your account these will also be disabled. So if your looking to advance in the game your gonna have to be online with a live active connection. On that note, my significant other who uses Wild Blue Satalight internet can play this game online with only a little hickup now and then, in which case the game normally automatically reconnects unlike others. So less you are running dial up or a version air card or something like that, DRM should be the least of your concerns. I Have a DSL connection and I have never once had a connection issue related to this game. Offline play is good if your at a friends house and just want to burn time or at an airport waiting for a plane but not good for long term play unless you dont mind playing one map or starting over repeatedly.  Over all I would give this game a 8 out of 10. Uplay is unneeded and accounts should be stored locally should you get disconnected so when you reconnect you dont have to reload a mission level or lose progress. Outside of that though the game is beautiful, runs fine, never crashed (yet), fun to play with hundreds of hours of play and replay and the randomization keeps everything interesting. I highly recommend this game over any other city/civilization builder. A solid sequel in the Anno series, unfortunately marred by Ubisoft's horrendous uPlay DRM and an obtrusive amount of cosmetic and functional DLC.   Anno 2070, while set in a futuristic dystopia and populated by factions divided by their approach to techology and resource preservation, is functionally identical to its predecessors. This is a good thing, as those mechanics are both fun and unique in the strategy genre.   In the Anno games you start out with a small settlement which you need to expand by building residences. As the population increases, they will begin to demand certain goods which you can provide by building production structures.   It is these production structures which drive the Anno series. Resources are not just produced from a single entity. Instead resources will need to move through a supply chain until they finally produce a finished good at the last stage. As your population advances and new demands emerge, you'll find your supply chains stretched thin as demand pulls raw resources and processed resources along multiple paths.  While a sandbox mode is available, In the campaign and several missions you'll face the additional challenge of enemy factions, requiring you to accomodate defensive and offensive production into your already complicated supply chains. I've only just started playing 2070, but I am already a big fan.  My first Anno game was 1503. I remember getting it when I was pretty young, when I was looking for Age of Empires 2. When I couldn't find a copy, I bought this instead. Being that I was young, I didn't fully get how to play, but I did immensely enjoy the experience.  Now, with 2070, the first game I've actively played since (I played a little of 1404, but not much) I can see soo much coming from this series.  The biggest plus for me is the music: A sense of foreboding with the end of the old world, but also a little bit of hope with the new one. Set in 2070, in a world partially flooded (presumably from global warming), you can choose between two main factions: The Industrial faction, and the Green faction. Each plays slightly different, but the mechanics are the same.  Mechanically, it's pretty similar to other Anno games. You set up a town, set trade routes with other settlements of your own and of other players, AI or real people. There is combat, but it's simplistic 'click here to kill' style. Fortunately, it isn't the focus of the game.  The game is infinitely replayable, if a tad repetitive. From what I've seen so far, there aren't too many visual differences between islands. There are multiple missions, a sandbox mode, asynchronous (thank goodness) multiplayer, and other things I haven't seen yet, but each mode starts almost identically. There's no problem with a bit of repetition, but that's just so you're aware of it.  In short, it's worth it, especially now it's on sale. You do need a steady internet connection to play it properly though.

Anno 2070 is a city builder with some real time strategy elements where you are tasked with providing the growing human refugee population, having lost their homes and land to rising ocean levels, with new cities built on now fertile highlands. Resource management is a MAJOR aspect of this game, ensuring efficiency and security of your supply lines, both on land and underwater, will make or break your either eco-friendly or mass-consumerist metropolises. Playing this game is definitely a time investment with many of the more advanced research projects taking an hour (or more) to complete, but there is a great satisfaction in seeing a project, like a dam, being implemented. There is a DRM element to the game, but this only applies to elections (which give a variety of temporary boosts to you) and your inventory on your ARK (which can carry over to other games). Gameplay includes missions of various sizes and lengths, multiplayer, and a continuous game mode where you can play for as long as you'd like. If you prefer to build then to destroy (or maybe like both) with your RTS then you should definitely look into this game.

A quick note to all people having trouble with Uplay: seriously guys, nothing can't be solved with google. Just download and install the newest version of Uplay before you install the game and Anno would run normally. Seems like Steam was too lazy to incorporate a newer version of Uplay into the game, hence all the hassles with it. Now that is out of the way, let's get to the game itself: I daresay this game is comparable to a gem. No, not the beautiful, gorgeous kind of gem, think of it more like a rough gem, that through progession, become more than rough. First 5 mins into Anno and I was INSTANTLY overwhelmed by just how much I have to learn. Firstly, you need building materials to build your city (duh!), but there's already a catch: all buildings require maintenance, and once I've set up all neccessary production building, my income was negative. To counter that, I need more people to settle in so I can tax them, and then I have to set up even more production buildings to support them. And what happen to a city with lots of people and industry? Yeap, pollution. Decreased happiness, Increased disaster rate, there's even a faction that would declare war upon anyone who destroy the ecobalance too much. Of course the game offer a solution to it: there are buildings that improve ecobalance, at the cost of hurting your economy (they require a fair amount of maintenance too).Then, as you progess, your people would require more than just basic food. They need activity, they need social services (Police, Fire Station, Hospital), they need more variety in food supply... which put EVEN MORE pressure on production chain. The game simply make it impossible to advance without expand, which then require a trade route, since, you know, goods ain't delivered themselves. Feeling dizzy yet? Good, because that's how the game keep you busy: and endless cycle of building, expanding, managing trades, fixing ecobalance, optimizing things... And did I mention there's a pirate faction and a private contractor, both of which would make your job even harder. To sum it up, Things I like: - Pretty graphics, you can feel the city grows as you progess, the people and traffic animation is also nice. - Solid gameplay, economy and production is consistent and makes sense to me. - Provide lots of depth, Anno can pretty much keep you busy for up to 20 hours without boredom. Things I don't like: - Tutorial is somewhat lacking, although there's an in-game AI assitant called 'EVE', she's really not that useful. My first city was a terrible mess just so I can learn what goes where. especially the trade management. If you can get your head around it in 10 mins, I envy you :( - Require alot of trial-and-error, you can literally have to spend up to 5 hours just to learn the basic. Hell, even youtube doesn't have a proper tutorial video. - Feels more like a economy management game and a city building game. But it's just my opinion really. Things I feel neutral: - Combat isn't polished, but hey, it's a city builder, of course the devs don't pay that much attention to combat system. - Late-game content: there's not much challenge to tackle once you advance to high tech tree. Your fleet can triple or even quadruple the size of your rival's fleets, you have access to nuclear missile and bomber that can obliterate anything, and your economy can support a perfect eco balance everywhere unless you mess up really, really bad. All in all, I give Anno a solid 9,5/10, and I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good city-building game.

Anno 2070.  The game looks and plays beautifully.   It features a reasonable length campaign and many individual scenarios, each with specific constraints and/or objectives. Additionally, an endless mode allows you to experience all the game has to offer. I haven't played much of the multiplayer, although there are several multiplayer modes, which can be played competitively or cooperatively. Due to the games length however you may struggle to finish a multiplayer game. Anno 2070 features a drop-in drop-out system, where players can be invited to, and leave games, allowing any remaining players to continue playing. Any player may take any saved multiplayer game and finish it solo.  Production chains are interesting, and require constant expanding and tweaking to maintain the ever increasing demand of your workers. I like this game, but it's definately missing something to make it a great game. I give it a 7.5 out of 10.  Installation was tricky and there is a very intrusive launcher, much like EA and Origin installer. However, the game would not load until I uninstalled uplay and went to their website to download it seperately and install. Once I got it up and running, there were few bugs and no crashes, which is a plus.  The premise of the game is simple. You settle and island with resources enough to build the basic starting structures. Each island has only a few basic resources, so you'll need to settle other islands to get accessed to more basic resources. Given there are three different factions with 4 levels of buildings in each plus a couple dozen basic resources that can be refined up to three different ways, you'll have lots to do. Even then, blueprints can be earned in a variety of ways to improve sectors, islands or units. You'll be attacked by other factions, and wage fights using an basic RTS interface.  Advancing your buildings can be daunting, but when you figure it out you are simply moving down a checklist of things you need to get, and then setting up a trade route to transfer it. Make no mistake, the checklists get to be a page long when you want to add a resource later in the game, but it isn't really challenging.  Anno 2070 plays like a city building game, but it never really felt like you were building a city. There was limited satisfaction in developing my island and very limited aesthetics or customization. The trading and economics were somewhat boring and static - bring resource X from place A to place B with ship Alpha so you can process it. The trading screen was overly simplistic.  The units and combat are right out of a 1990s RTS game that was dumbed down a ton. Which is a good thing since it's touted as a city building / strategy game. It's bad because you could remove it and the game would actually be better. I'd convert it to a more tower based game where you survive 'waves' or events that happen every 3 minutes. You could also make Anno a 100% strategy game where units aren't controlled directly, or a mission based game where units are more like hero units that embark on quests.  Is Anno 2070 good? I'm not really sure. I had a good time playing it through and it was highly addictive. There is always something to do. However, after a few dozen hours playing it was an easy delete off my system. I'm not really sure if a game like this can stand out. It does a lot of things well, but a lot poorly as well. However, it was definately worth my money and time to give it a spin.

SimCity + Civilization + Waterworld  Anno 2070 takes an indirect approach to the strategy/citybuilding game, with a severely reduced focus on warfare, and an interesting mechanic of tech advancement. Instead of simply building your way to 'Tech 2' and beyond, you advance your technology by meeting the needs of your citizens. It's a different approach that pays off well by indirectly forcing exploration and trade.  However, as a strategy title, the combat is restricted to the point of periphery. Warships are expensive, but do not deliver pleasing results. And battles are usually facepalmingly overwhelming when fighting AI. Combat is definitely it's lowest selling point.  The multiplayer was not remarkable, and neither was the campaign, but I found myself sucked into that  'just one more turn'  sensation not usually found in RTS titles. There's strong incentive to keep playing long after you've won, and the setting is fun to explore, from your first underwater dive to your final aerial domination.   TL;DR  Nice visuals, and interesting premise, and a unique spin on resource management got well over 40 hours from me. I had quite a bit of fun with Anno, though others are advised to check playthroughs before purchasing.

I have had a few problems with the launcher but I've had the game before the x-pack came out for it and I am still able to play it just even today. Campaign is quite fun and doesn't feel the same all the time. With the x-pack more options and game play mechanics are more fun to mess with. I have played Anno 2205 and that didn't capture my attention like 2070 did. Free build is always fun to see how much you can squeeze out of your production chains to attain max population it can handle. Definitely recommend (though the launcher does suck) but being on sale during black Friday for $4.99, if you have been eying this game, now would be the time to get it.
